editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A COMIC OPERA, IN THREE ACTS.
NOW PERFORMING AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN.
LONDON: PRINTED AND PUBLISHED BY GEORGE CAWTHORN, BRITISH LIBRARY, STRAND.

list.head: Men.
list.item: BAILIFFS, Mr. Grey and Mr. Street.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: A Room in Sir Simon Flourish's House. Enter SIR SIMON and OLD TESTY.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: BUT, my good friend Testy, do lower the pitch of your voice a little; for to speak so very loud is really not well-bred.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: I'll speak as loud as I like, and say what I like. Damn your fine breeding!‚Äîan ounce of honesty is worth an hundred weight of it.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: There now‚Äîounce and hundred weight! Can't you contrive to think, and talk a little like a Man of Fashion? When you quitted business, you shou'd have dispos'd of your vulgarity with your stock in trade. Copy me. Do you find any thing vulgar about me?

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Psha! you and I liv'd too long together to think of cajoling each other: you are as vulgar as I am‚ÄîI wish you were half as honest.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: My good friend, if we are not to attempt cajoling each other, the less you say about your honesty the better.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Why, what have you to say against my honesty?

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Nothing, I am too well bred: beside, I was your partner in trade for twenty-five years.‚ÄîI reap'd half the profits of your ingenuity, and had you been honester, I might be poorer. But, my dear friend, let us settle our business a little quietly, if you will be so kind. Your son, you say, is come to town:‚Äîgood. You insist he may be introduc'd to our ward, Miss Hartley:‚Äîhe shall.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: That's fair.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: I thought you'd say so; because 'tis very unfair to my own son, who being absent from England, ought not to have a rival introduc'd to the Lady I wish to be his wife. But remember, as she cannot marry without our joint consent, we must agree, that which ever she prefers shall have our mutual approbation.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Why, yes.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Ah! mine is the boy that will win her! Educated with every advantage; now receiving the last polish, the finishing stroke to his accomplishments, in a Tour through Europe!‚ÄîOh! he is a‚Äî

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Yes, he is a pretty boy. That youth will put foreign ingenuity to the test. If they can send him away more dissipated than they find him, I will give them credit for one miracle.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Leave your growling, good Mr. Bear, and look after your own unlick'd cub. His country breeding will render him vastly pleasing to a young lady!

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: He is a model of perfection. Innocent himself, he will never suspect that evil exists, that may make him liable to imposition: but I have adopted a remedy in my choice of a profession for him.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: As how, pray?

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: To render him in some degree a match for the roguery of the world, I shall make him a Lawyer.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: And I dare say, his Yorkshire simplicity will qualify him admirably for the profession!

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Well, Flourish, the only thing we were ever in one mind about, was parting, and I conclude you have no objection to it now.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: None in the least.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: I shall send my son, and mind, fair play's the word.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Certainly (Testy going). Let me see you out.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Oh! damn your civility! Stay where you are.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: (Alone.) Oh! you pretty behaved, accomplished creature! Is it not strange, that in so many years acquaintance, the polish of my manners shold not have induced him to rub off his vulgar rust!

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Captain O'Neill, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Shew the Captain in. [Exit Servant.

div.p: I rejoice to see you, Captain O'Niell. You are welcome to town.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: Sir Simon Flourish, your most obedient.‚ÄîPermit me to enquire after her Ladyship, and your lovely ward, Miss Hartley.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Both in fine health and spirits; and they will very much regret not being at home to receive you.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: Proud as I am always to pay them my profound respects, at this moment my business lies entirely with you, Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Oh Lord! I hope he don't want to borrow money of me (Aside). Your commands, if you please, Captain.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: An affair of honour compels me to be troublesome to you.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: An affair of honour compels him to be troublesome to me! Oh, that is worse than borrowing money. (Aside)

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: My wounded reputation must be heal'd.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Oh Lord! Oh Lord! How have I offended him? (Aside.)

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: Slander can only be washed out with blood.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Oh! my precious blood! Oh dear! Oh dear! I suppose I have said some ill natur'd thing of him behind his back, for I am sure I never durst affront him to his face. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: A little after your leaving Bath‚Äî

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: A little after my leaving Bath! (repeats falteringly.) Oh yes, some damn'd good-natur'd friend blabb'd when my back was turned (aside). Why really, Captain, I don't recollect what can have given you offence at Bath.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: That I readily believe; for it would be hard to expect you to recollect what you never heard.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Eh!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: I say, Sir Simon, you cannot be expected to know the insult offer'd me, by a man who did not arrive till you were gone.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p:
Oh, the man that insulted you did not arrive till I was gone! Lord, what a load is off my
mind! (Aside.) And so Captain, a villain had the audacity to insult you.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: I was insulted, Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: You'll not let him live. You'll tear him to atoms‚ÄîI know you will‚ÄîBlood and thunder! if it were my case‚Äî

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: Be cool, Sir Simon‚Äîyou are too desperate.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: I am‚ÄîI know it is my fault; but fire and fury!‚ÄîCan I assist you in this business?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: That is the very cause of my visit to you‚ÄîWill you honour me so far as to deliver a bit of a message for me?

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: What, carry a challenge for you? (eagerly.)

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: Exactly.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: What, and be your Second?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: If I may take the liberty to ask such a favour?

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: My dear Captain, give me your hand. I am the happiest man alive to serve a friend. I'll see you through this affair; I'll take care of you. Where am I to go? What am I to do first?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: Why, first of all, there is a little preparatory business. Before I can receive satisfaction for the injury done me, I must put it in the power of my adversary to give it me.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: As how, pray?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: You must know, the young man is unluckily in prison for debt: and as he has friends who are able to release him, I thought it wou'd be taking a liberty to rob them of a pleasure they have the best right to;‚Äîbut they scorn to be outdone in politeness, and, I believe, wou'd let him remain till doomsday, before they would dispute the point with me.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: And so you mean to pay his debts on purpose to fight him?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: I do, and I wish I had a better motive; for though injur'd honour demands atonement, I wou'd rather do one little bit of a kindness than revenge a thousand injuries.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Will it cost you much?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: More than is quite convenient, and therefore I must trespass on your goodness in a second instance.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Eh! what, how?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: I shall be under the necessity of troubling you for three hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p:
Lord! it is a vast deal of money: I think you had better not fight him till there is an Act of Insolvency. Or, could'nt you get a snug little room in the Prison, and fight him at his own home; that would be more genteel and accommodating. No, no‚Äîplague take it, that won't do; for if you kill him, they will keep
us there. I should like to see you fight amazingly, but then to pay three hundred pounds for it, it is very dear: I only paid a guinea to see Johnson and Big Ben, and their way of fighting is quite as fashionable now-a days!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: Understand me, Sir Simon. I don't intend to be under an obligation to you or any man. I have brought my Commission as security for the sum.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Security! my dear friend, do you think I want security? That is like a Trader; there is no security with People of Fashion. Yet I may as well take it by way of memorandum. (Takes the Commission.) Well, tell me who he is, and where he is to be found. I'll carry him the money and the challenge.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: Oh! by no means. He must not know the money comes from me. He may feel it unpleasant to be under an obligation to a man he has wrong'd; and to know that I had injur'd his feelings, would not be the way to satisfy mine.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: You are a very strange man! There is the money, manage it your own way.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NIELL.
sp.p: I thank you, and as soon as he has got the miseries of a prison a little out of his mind, you shall wait on him.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: As soon as you please. The sooner the better.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEILL.
sp.p: You are too impetuous, you fiery little fellow! We must not be in a hurry, for misfortune is apt to lower a man's spirit, and I scorn to meet a foe in a state of degradation.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Well, you must act as you chuse, only fight soon, for I shall think of nothing else. I know I am a desperate dog. When I was at school, they us'd to call me the little Game-Cock. You are to do as you like, but were it my own affair, I should stand close, muzzle to muzzle, toe to toe.‚ÄîDamme, I'd fight him in a saw-pit. I wonder I have not fought yet. I never was even ask'd to be a Second till now; but, I believe, I know pretty well from the newspapers what a Second has to do:‚ÄîTo load the pistols, measure the ground, take care they stand near enough, and let them fire as long as they like. I believe that is all. Oh no! If the parties are wounded, he is to leave them on the ground, to the mercy of chance, and take care of himself.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEILL.
sp.p: I am not to dictate your conduct, Sir Simon; only it might be well if every Second would consider that his office is that of a Friend to adjust an affair of Honour‚ñ™ not of a Sheriff to witness an execution. Good morning, Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p:
(Alone.) What a lucky dog I am! To be concerned in a Duel was the only thing wanting to compleat me as a Man of Fashion. I shall state the case next day in the newspapers, with my name at full length. Then a glorious confusion always takes place! People just remember the names, but forget whether they were
Principals or Seconds! Oh! my character will be up! I shall be a Man of Fashion indeed!

div.stage: Enter Lady FLOURISH and Miss HARTLEY.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: My dear, Sir Simon! how glad I am you're at home! If I am ever so little a while away from you, my darling, it appears a long, tedious age. How does my lovy do? Do look tender! 'tis so becoming to you; and beside, if you don't, you know you break my heart.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Now really, Lady Flourish, you are too fond before company, indeed you are. 'Tis your only fault, my dear. But you ought to consider, that to be fond of a husband at all, is very unfashionable; and therefore, when a wife feels that amiable weakness, she ought never to expose it before people.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: But I can't help exposing it. Miss Hartly knows I have been talking of nothing else but my dearest the whole time I have been out: all the while I was buying my china, and my gold muslins, and my lace, I was longing to be at home with my darling.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Lord, my dear: I wish you had indulg'd your longing, and then you wou'd n't have laid out so much money. And how is my dear Miss Hartley? You don't seem in spirits.

sp.speaker: MISS HARTLEY.
sp.p: Indeed I am not: but the cause of my want of spirits must remain a secret to you. (Aside). They, sir, who, like me, never knew misfortune, are apt to trifle with their felicity.

lg.l: THE heart that has ne'er tasted sorrow,
E'en happiness often will cloy;
And we ever from misery borrow
Our knowledge of exquisite joy.
To those who all anguish wou'd smother,
The best use of life is unknown;
To feel for the woes of another,
Or value the bliss that's their own.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Old Testy's stupid bumpkin of a son is to be introduced to you this morning: but there is no fear of his rivalling my boy Jack. How I long to see the rogue again! Where is he now, I wonder? May be, eating macaroni with the Grand Duke, or having the honour of kissing the toe of his Holinesss the Pope. Oh! what high fellows my son is living with!

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: Where ever he is, my dearest, he can meet nobody so fine a gentleman as his papa.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Oh! you are too partial, Lady Flourish‚Äîa great deal, a great deal too partial. I have news for you‚ÄîCaptain O'Neill has been here.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: Captain O'Neill in town? (Earnestly.)

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p:
I shou'd like to tell them of his engaging me to be his Second. (Aside). You know the Captain is a man of great bravery, and knowing me to be of the same turn‚Äîhum! hum we have
had a good deal of conversation on the subject of Duelling

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: I hope the Captain is not going to fight a Duel‚ñ™ (Greatly alarm'd).

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Oh dear, no.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: I am glad to hear you say so. I was quite agitated at the thought of any friend of your's being engag'd in so horrid a business.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: I must not blab, I find. She'd lay an information, and destroy my renown. Were I a Principal instead of a Second, I shou'd be vastly oblig'd to her. (Aside.) I wonder how many Duels Jack has fought abroad‚Äîthat is, fought, or been Second in? 'Tis just the same thing. The credit is the same, and so is the danger pretty nearly; for the Principals are often so cursedly frighten'd, that it is an even chance whether they hit their antagonist, or their own Second.

sp.speaker: MISS HARTLEY.
sp.p: Though I abhor the practice, yet when men deem such trials necessary, I hope they conduct themselves with proper courage.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: That is mighty well of you. You don't know what it is to receive a man's fire, or you wou'd not talk so lightly about it.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Young Mr. Testy, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: Come, my dear, rest yourself a little before you encounter the fatigue of this Bumpkin's conversation.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Ay, do; I'll talk to him first.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Well, Tom, I'm glad to see you: you are welcome to London. Oh! what a Quiz it is!

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Thank you, thank you, Sir Simon. Lord! Lord! why you be quite another guise kind of a man than what you us'd to be! I remember, as thof it was but yesterday, when father and you us'd to weigh I and Jack Flourish in the great warehouse scales, and I always were heaviest.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Yes, and you'll continue heaviest as long as you live‚ñ™ But, Tom, don't talk about weights and scales, 'tis so vulgar. Damn Trade, and all that belongs to it. I am a Gentleman and a Knight now.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Yes, Sir Simon‚ñ™ so they tell me; but for all that‚ñ™ don't damn Trade; for I don't think as how you'd a' been a Gentleman and a Knight, if the money you got by the warehouse had not given you a bit of a lift.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Oh the vulgar young dog! [Aside.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Well, Sir Simon, father sent me a courting, and so, you see, I am come; so no more words, let's set about it.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Oh yes, with all my heart. I'll see if Miss Hartley is ready to receive you. What a young Savage! I dare say they wou'd buy him at Exeter 'Change. [Exit.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Well, faint heart never won fair lady. Dang it, I'll shew her a Yorkshire boy is not afraid of a pretty girl.

lg.l: I NE'ER by a lass yet was scouted,
I know the right method to get her,
No cringing for me,
I'll soon let her see
That I'm bold, and she'll like me the better.
I'm a boy that's not easily flouted,
If she give herself airs, why e'en let her,
When to kiss her I try,
"You're rude," Sir, she'll cry,
Why I am, and you like me the better.
When she finds that I'm not to be routed,
And at morn, noon, and night I beset her,
She'll alter her tone,
And readily own
Tho' I'm rude, that she likes me the better.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Another Room in Sir Simon's House. Enter SIR SIMON FLOURISH and KITTY.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: And now give me a kiss, you little rogue you. [Kisses her.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Lord! Sir Simon, how can you be so rude!

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Now, Kitty, mind you say all the ill-natur'd things you can to your young Mistress of this Country Blockhead. Always praise my son Jack to her, and he'll bring you over trinkets enough for you to set up a raffle-shop at Margate. Here the Booby comes. Now you may go and fetch Miss Hartley.

div.p: There, Mr. Testy, good bye: I leave you to your love-making. What a Lout it is!

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: So this be young Madam that father wants me to marry. Egad she is a tight lass enow!‚ÄîWell, Miss, and so father says as how he wishes I'd marry you; and so, d'ye see, if you've no mighty objection, we may even be ax'd in church together.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: What does the Booby mean! Lord, he takes me for my Mistress! Not such a Booby as I thought him. [Aside.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Why, you don't answer, Miss. Speak out‚Äîdon't be shame-fac'd. So, as I was saying, I have no disliking to you, nor liking for any body else, and if you have no particular disliking to me more than to other people, I dare say we shall be as happy a couple as goes.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Gemini, what a flutter I am in! If I can but make him believe I am my Mistress, my fortune is made. I must try to behave like a Lady; but if I am modest, like my Mistress, I shall never pass upon him. No, no, I must be free and dashing, as fine Ladies are in general. (Aside.) Why, young man, I have been considering what you have been saying; and, as I don't think you quite so great a brute as I expected you to be, I don't much care if I take you upon trial.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Take me upon trial!‚ÄîWhat, does she make a horse of me? But dang it, free and easy‚ÄîI like her the better. But mayhap, Miss, if I am not so great a brute now, I may be a greater when I am married. Ah! what do you say to that, my tight Filly?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: I'll do all I can to make you fashionable.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Thank you, thank you. I'll do as much for you. Dang it, I didn't think I should have been so much at home with a fine Lady.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: What is your name, young man?

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Tom Testy.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Well, Tom.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Tom! How familiar and kind!

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: I'll have you Tom. 'Tis a bargain.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Is it? There's my hand, and my lips too, I like you. How little we know in Yorkshire about London folk. They told me, you fine Ladies were squeamish and shy, and all that nonsense.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: No, Tom. That is quite gone by in high life.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: So much the better. Well, but Miss, and when shall we be married? Hey! let it be soon.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: When you like, 'tis all one to me. Only, Tom, don't mention it, let us be snug. We'll steal a march; marry first, and tell the old ones after.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: So we will: that will be good ≈øun.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Now mind, when you go home to your father, you don't tell him what we have settled.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: No, not I; but I don't live at father's; I've got a place of my own, do as I like, live in the Temple. I am to be a Counsellor, father says, and a plaguy good one I shall make; for it is all done by eating, and I have a fine appetite, if the London air don't spoil it. Lord, what a happy life we shall lead!

lg.l: WHEN I'm married, I'll be gay,
Still flaunting as shall please me;
Careless what I do or say,
No power on earth shall teaze me.
If you e'er, in jealous spite,
Should hint at horns ideal,
Then my way to set you right
Will be‚Äîto make them real.
Husbands, now, for horns who care,
Must be less wise than nice, Ma'am,
While, at market, horns will bear
So very high a price, Ma'am:
And for Lawyers too, like me,
No trouble it at all is,
Since horn-fair remov'd we see
To Westminster old Hall is.
Then since we agree so easy to be,
Let's marry as soon as we can;
For, not to demur, whate'er may occur,
Is surely the very best plan.

div.head: SCENE III.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p:
Was ever man more miserably circumstanced? Bred up as heir to a splendid fortune,
and all my hopes destroy'd, by the caprice of a splenetic old uncle. Shut up here, in the King's Bench, for debt; and, not only depriv'd of the happiness of beholding the woman I adore, but asham'd to acquaint her with the wretchedness of my situation.

lg.l: ONCE, all that cou'd enchant the sight,
Enraptur'd fancy drew,
And deck'd each prospect of delight
With tints of brightest hue.
In fairy loveliness array'd,
The beauteous objects shone,
While charm'd I gaz'd, Hope sweetly said,
"These prospects are thine own."
But fancy, now, from forms of joy,
Averts her sick'ning sight;
Her pencil horrors wild employ,
And scenes of blackest night;
The dismal pictures rise to view
Where direst ills combine,
Despair exclaims, "bid Hope adieu,
These prospects now are thine."

div.stage: Enter a Servant belonging to the Prison.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Mr. Flourish, Sir, has sent you the book of travels he borrow'd; and says he will call on you presently.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: That good humour'd, whimsical fellow, Flourish, is always welcome to me.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p:
It is queer enough that his father, Sir Simon
Flourish, should be humm'd so as to think he is going the Tour of Europe, when, all the while, he never got a step farther than St. George's Fields. [Exit.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Here he comes.
sp.stage: [Young Flourish singing without. Over the Hills, &c.

div.stage: Enter in a shabby light-colour'd Coat, with black Breeches and Boots.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Ah! my boy, Harcourt, how are you?

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Why Jack, what makes you booted?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: A man ought to be booted, when he's on a journey. An't I going the Tour of Europe?

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Oh! I beg your pardon. I had forgot; but you don't seem furnish'd with a very elegant riding‚ñ™dress‚Äîboots and black are not very correct‚Äîhey!

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: The customs of countries differ; but to tell you the truth, so much travelling has made vast havock among my leather, and as for my black small clothes, I wear them as mourning for the demise of my last colour'd pair.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: But my dear Jack, what can be the joke of your staying in this sad place?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: All the joke was in getting here. Staying is not quite so comical.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: But, Jack, I must know what brought you here?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Poll.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Poll!‚ÄîWhat Poll?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Not know Poll?‚ÄîWhere the devil have you liv'd?‚ÄîNot know Poll?‚ÄîWhy Poll is the rage‚ÄîIn Hyde Park every morning‚Äîrides the best horse‚Äîdrives the best curricle‚Äîgives the best dinners‚Äîdamme, the first Dutchess in the land envies Poll!

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: I beg Poll's pardon for not knowing her.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: So you ought, for Poll's familiar and kind, she'd have no objection to knowing you. But the thing is, father said I shou'd be a Man of Fashion, and so I am, an't I?‚ÄîDamme, you still look at my legs‚Äîwell, black-legs don't make me a bit less a Man of Fashion.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Oh! by no means.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Well.‚ÄîBut about Poll‚ÄîAs I was to be a Man of Fashion, who so proper to make me one as Poll? Poll has made and unmade half the fine men of the day. I kept Poll when I was at school; Poll stuck to me at college; and when father fix'd I should travel, and see the world, who so fit to shew it me as Poll?

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Well, why did n't Poll shew it you?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: She did, she shew'd me here.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: But why not take her abroad with you?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: She wou'd not go. Poll said she wou'd do any thing but cross the water with me. And I could not find in my heart to go abroad without her. So I touch'd father's cash, and resolv'd to finish my education in my own country.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Very patriotic, truly!

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Well, father went to Bath‚ÄîI staid in town‚Äîthe money flew‚ÄîPoll knew how to dash it. When all was gone, it was natural enough to come here, you know.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: But how were you able to leave Poll?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: She did not trouble me to think about that: when the money was gone, Poll left me.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: So Poll wou'd not follow your fortunes to the King's Bench!‚ÄîHow unkind!

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: So I told her‚Äî"Ah, Poll!" said I, "'tis damn'd ill-natur'd to leave me."

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: And what did she say?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: She only laugh'd and said,‚Äî"She told me at first, she'd do any thing but cross the water with me."

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: You must throw yourself on your father's mercy at last, and the sooner you do it the better.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: For me?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: No, Sir,‚Äîfor Mr. Harcourt.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Ah! nobody writes to me.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: (Reads.) "I am led to believe the enclos'd notes will liberate you. They are sent for that purpose."‚ÄîAstonishing!‚ÄîNo name.‚ÄîDoes any body wait?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: No, Sir. [Exit.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: This must be from my dear girl.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Ah! you are a happy fellow! Your dear girl writes to you. Though Poll would not cross the water, she might send me a letter now and then. It is damn'd unkind.‚ÄîBut no, no, poor girl, I shou'dn't scold her for what she can't help. I ought to remember, Poll can't write.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: This must be my Harriot's generosity. Charming girl! How could she discover my situation?‚ÄîBut what will not Love discover?‚Äî

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: So, you're going to leave me. 'Tis devillsh hard to be cut by every body.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Depend on it, my dear fellow, I will be with you soon.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Ah! do come and see me. Don't be like Poll, afraid of crossing the water.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: No, Jack‚Äîdepend upon it. Adieu!‚ÄîNow to my charming girl.‚Äî [Exit.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Ah! your's is a charming girl, indeed, to send you money.‚ÄîIf Poll had a million, I dare say she wou'dn't think of sending me a shilling, and yet she us'd to say she lov'd me vastly.

lg.l: WHEN to my pretty Poll I went,
And I to travel sought her,
"Ah, stay at home, dear Jack," says she,
"I cannot cross the water."
What could I do? Away I flew,
A curricle I bought her;
Six smoaking bays, all Hyde Park's gaze,
From Tattersall's I brought her.
"Dear Jack," says she, "how kind you be!
(She'd coax like Eve's own daughter,)
"With you will I both live and die,
"Do all but cross the water."
Then, splashing, dashing through the town,
She drove, the stare of all,
The echo of her rattling wheels
Was, "There goes pretty Poll!"
"Oh, pretty, pretty Poll!"
From ev'ry tongue the echo rung
"See, there goes pretty Poll!"
What a lad then was I!
All to dress at me try,
And my praise to withhold none so currish,
With a girl so divine,
Such dinners! such wine!
What a damn'd clever dog was Jack Flourish!
But an end to my cash,
And my fame goes to smash,
No friends my good qualities nourish;
For they, once so kind,
Now agree in one mind,
What a damn'd stupid flat is Jack Flourish!
Thus, cut by my friends, by bailiffs seiz'd,
And this vile limbo near,
Yet with one hope I still was pleas'd,
That Poll my cage wou'd cheer.
To Poll I told where I must go,
And not to leave me sought her;
She, laughing, cried, "Dear Jack, you know
"I cannot cross the water."

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: A Garden belonging to Sir Simon's House. HARRIOT discovered (alone).
div.p: How distressing is my Harcourt's absence! and the mysterious concealment of his residence encreases my anxiety! Can he think so meanly of me, as to suppose his loss of fortune will lesson my affection?

lg.l: NOT mine the narrow soul, assur'd,
In riches joy to find;
Not mine by title's glare allur'd,
To genuine merit blind.
In wealth and rank who seek for bliss,
Contempt or pity move,
They never chuse so much amiss,
Whose hearts were form'd for love.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: My life!

sp.speaker: HARRIOT.
sp.p: Oh Charles!

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: My angel, what a tedious absence!

sp.speaker: HARRIOT.
sp.p: If my Charles thought it so, why not sooner fly to his adoring Harriot?

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: I follow'd you to Bath, but, unluckily you had left it the day before I arriv'd; and what then happen'd I could not prevail on myself to disclose to you: I was resolv'd to bear my misfortunes alone; but your kindness has dispell'd them, and now I fly with gratitude to thank my deliverer.

sp.speaker: HARRIOT.
sp.p: Your deliverer!

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Yes, my Harriot! attempt not to conceal your generous conduct. But for you, a prison wou'd have been my habitation for life.

sp.speaker: HARRIOT.
sp.p: A prison, Charles! Has such been your distress, and yet conceal it from me?

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Can it be possible that I am not indebted to you for my deliverance?

sp.speaker: HARRIOT.
sp.p: By concealing from me your situation, you prevented me from being your deliverer. Oh, Charles! that was a false pride, which avoided the assistance of her who loves you. True affection shou'd seek occasions for receiving kindness, conscious it bestows most delight when it affords the power of obliging.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Pardon me, Harriot‚ñ™ Poverty will be proud. But what am I to think? See here, my love, this cover enclosed notes sufficient to discharge my debts.

sp.speaker: HARRIOT.
sp.p: Whoever has had the pleasure of releasing you, claims my gratitude, yet excites my envy.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Generous girl! To avoid suspicion, I had better leave you now, my Harriot.

lg.l: AH, must you away while nature's so gay,
And all things to happiness move!
Hark! the feather'd warbler's throat
Pours of joy the swelling note,
'Tis inspir'd by the spirit of love.
Ah! wert thou away, 'twould cease to be gay‚ñ™
No longer to happiness move,
'Tis thou art the soul
Gives life to the whole,
And infuses the spirit of love.
Hark! the tuneful current near
Sweetly steals upon mine ear;
And its gentle murmurs prove
'Tis inspir'd by the spirit of love.
Ah, dear girl, wert thou not here,
No more these sounds wou'd sweet appear,
The murm'ring stream wou'd cease to provc
'Tis inspir'd by the spirit of love.
Ah, dear youth, wert thou away,
Ah, dear girl, wert thou away,
No more wou'd nature's face be gay,
No more each sound wou'd sweetly prove
'Tis inspir'd by the spirit of love!

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Sir Simon's House. Enter Lady FLOURISH and KITTY.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: Kitty, did you see Old Testy's Yorkshire prodigy when he was here?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Yes, my Lady.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: I conclude he is a shocking Saracen.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Yes, my Lady.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: I suppose Miss Hartley votes him a sad bore.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Lord, your Ladyship! I could not think of Miss Hartley being troubled with such a brute of a fellow, especially, my Lady, as his Honour Sir Simon designs Miss for his own son; so, an't please you, my Lady, I sent him away with a flea in his ear.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: Captain O'Niel, I am prodigiously happy to see you. Kitty, you need not wait.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: I protest and vow, that meeting your Ladyship gives me the most superlative pleasure.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: Why then, I protest and vow the pleasure is mutual.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Your Ladyship does me a great deal of honour. I will beg of her Ladyship to say a kind word for me to Miss Hartley, for I want very much to be thought well of by that lovely girl. [Aside] I am glad to find your Ladyship alone.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: Glad to find me alone, Captain?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Prodigiously so, my Lady. I have a favour to beg of your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: A favour of me! I hope, Captain, you are not going to ask any thing improper?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: I hope your Ladyship will not think it so.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: Indeed but I shall, if I ought to think it so; for tho' you are a very pretty man, and very much of a gentleman, and dance delightfully, and have a profusion of elegant accomplishments,‚Äîand‚Äî

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, Madam, you confuse me.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: Do I?‚ÄîWell, I protest 'tis very becoming to you. Confusion seems quite natural to you; but I will have compassion on your modesty.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: It is very generous in your Ladyship to compassionate a national infirmity. Bashfulness‚ñ™ and the brogue always go together. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t let me intreat you to take an interest in my happiness‚ñ™

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: I take an interest in your happiness! You'll absolutely make me faint.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: What shou'd your Ladyship faint about? Why, my Lady, I but desire‚Äî

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: Oh! you shou'd conquer your desires!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: But I only wish‚Äî

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: Fie, fie! I must not gratify your wishes.‚ÄîDon't press me any further; for tho' I have a great deal of resolution, you have an infinity of insinuation.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: I wish you would let me insinuate my meaning‚Äî

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: Don't shock me. I know what you want to insinuate.‚ÄîThink what a dreadful thing it is to seduce the wife of your friend.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: My Lady‚Äî

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: Oh, Captain O'Neil! how can you go to persuade me to be unfaithful to poor, dear, little Sir Simon?

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Can I believe my ears? Why fire and fury, Captain O'Neil! how durst you think of such a thing!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Here's a blessed piece of a blunder.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: Sir Simon, I'm quite shock'd at your intrusion. How can you be so ill-bred? I beg you'll not interfere with my concerns. "I am myself the guardian of my honour, and will not brook so insolent a monitor." [Exit.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Oh you Violator of Friendship! Oh you Seducer! Why, Tarquin was a Joseph to you!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Sir Simon, upon my honour, I meant not the least harm.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Why, did I not hear her say, you wanted her to be unfaithful to poor, dear, little Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Will you hear me, Sir Simon?

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: No, you monster of iniquity! you wanted to separate a pair of fine turtle-doves.‚ÄîYou deluder of innocence, you destroyer of the peace of families!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Very well, Sir Simon, I plainly see what you mean. You are too fond of fighting to listen to reason; and since nothing but spilling my innocent blood will appease you, I must submit. There, Sir Simon, (Pulling out pistols.) I little thought to cock either of these against you.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Cock them against me!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: (Pointing to Sir Simon.) Take your choice, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Take my choice! No, I shan't take my choice.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Oh, you may trust to them‚Äîthey have done execution in their time. But may be, you don't think one a piece enough? Well, then, fetch a pair of your own I'll measure out a few paces while you are gone.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: [With horror.] A few paces!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Oh! I beg your pardon: I had forgot‚Äîyou like to fight muzzle to muzzle.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Muzzle to muzzle! Oh Lord! Oh Lord!‚Äî

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Well, I must assent to your savage propensities. I must fight you how you like.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: But damme, if I'll fight you at all.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Not fight me! Oh! the patience of St. Patrick cou'd not brook such contemptuous treatment! You won't even fight me?

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: I won't, upon my soul.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: You positively refuse to treat me like a gentleman? O what extremities you drive me to! (Strikes him with his cane.) How can you distress me so!

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: How the devil can you distress me so?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Not fight me? Oh 'tis cruel treatment! (Striking him again.)

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: It is, upon my soul.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Now, will you fight me?

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: You are taking the worst way in the world to persuade me.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: I'll try it a little more, however. (Holding up his cane.)

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Hold, for mercy! I'll ask your pardon‚Äîanything‚ÄîWhat will satisfy you?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Nothing that a poltroon can offer. I am sorry I have degraded myself by striking a coward.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: So am I‚Äîvery.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Oh, you are a desperate dog! You wou'd stand close, toe to toe‚Äîmuzzle to muzzle‚ÄîDamme, you'd fight in a saw-pit. Oh, you are a pretty fellow for a Second!

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Very well for a Second, but not quite so well for a Principal. But, Captain, I hope you'll be kind enough not to mention this trifling affair; for 'tis a pity, the reputation a man has been collecting his whole life, should be whisk'd away in a moment.‚ÄîWhat a vapour Honour is, that it will fly away in the dusting a coat! Do be tender, Captain‚ÄîPray don't mention this!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: In my opinion, you are too contemptible to be mentioned at all.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Your opinion I shall always have the highest respect for.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Good bye, my little game-cock. I shall remember you always stand muzzle to muzzle.‚ÄîOh, you are a desperate dog indeed‚ñ™ [Exit.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: (Alone.) I have been very unlucky. I am afraid I have not acted quite like a Man of Fashion. In the first place, to interrupt a Gentleman's making love to my wife, was not at all like a Man of Fashion‚Äîno‚Äîthat was very low breeding indeed. As to getting a beating‚Äîthat will happen to Men of Fashion, now and then. But one part of my behaviour, I hope, sets all to rights‚ÄîI behav'd very ill, and I ask'd pardon. If that is not like a Man of Fashion, the devil's in't. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Inside of the King's Bench, with a View of the High Wall. Enter Young FLOURISH.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: I have been puzzling over maps, these two hours, to find out where I have been, or rather where I ought to have been; and 'tis a great deal more troublesome to travel in imagination than in reality: for I must keep my eyes open, while I am tracing my journey on paper; but if I had gone it in earnest, I might have slept comfortably from post to post, as most Travellers do!

div.p: Ah! Charles, my boy, coming to see me so soon is kind indeed!

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: And I have brought a friend to see you.

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p: What a mighty queer world we live in! This is a gentleman I am proud to hear call me friend‚Äîand yet half an hour ago I was ready to cut his throat!

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Cut your friend's throat?

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p: Why, it happens every day‚Äîdon't it? Your making a wonder of that proves you live out of the world.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: By your account, to live out of the world seems the only chance one has to live at all.

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p: You are pretty right there; for between those who, having too little courage, want to be thought to have enough, and those who have so much, 'tis always boiling over‚Äîa quiet man's life is in a constant state of requisition.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: But, how came you two to quarrel?

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p: The only way that two honest men can quarrel‚Äîby mistake.‚ÄîHowever, before we troubled our pistols to speak for us, we thought it no dishonour to speak a little for ourselves; by which means we found out, that though we met to settle a dispute, devil a dispute we had to settle.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: How was that?

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p:
Why, it appears that this same good looking
countenance of mine is unlucky enough to resemble the phiz of a Gentleman Blacklegs, who by a little trick or two in the way of his trade, disburthen'd our friend of his cash. He thought, when he met me in the Rooms at Bath, (and the place, to be sure‚ñ™ was not much in my favour) that he had nick'd his man and accosted me accordingly. We lost one another in the croud, and he departed in his error. I learnt his name, and follow'd him to London; where, if I hadn't had wisdom enough to ask an explanation, I might have been sent out of the world for the misfortune of resembling a scoundrel.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: How much I must ever feel bound to you!

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p: Ah! Harcourt, appearances are very deceitful, and he who forms his opinions from them will blunder on in the dark, let the sun shine ever so bright.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: And that is blundering indeed.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Captain O'Neil‚Äîmy friend, Jack Flourish, is a very whimsical fellow.‚ÄîIf he had been out of Limbo, you wou'd have seen him earlier; for I shou'd have brought him for my Second.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: No, you would not; for to be Second in a Duel is, in my mind, an employment pretty nearly as honourable as to be Jack Ketch's Deputy.

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p: All the Flourishes are not of that opinion. I presume you are no relation to that little game-cock, Sir Simon?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: My father a little game-cock?

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p: Sir Simon your father! Why, Sir Simon's son is on his travels.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Yes, Sir Simon's son travels like a millhorse, a great deal in a small space. But here he is, here's Jack Flourish, and if he had not had the wisdom to stay at home, he wou'd have lost the good fortune of becoming acquainted with you. He is a fool who quits Old England‚Äîfor damme, if he'll find such fellows any where as he leaves behind him.

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p: I should be jealous of your praise, if Old England and Old Ireland were not exactly the same spot of ground. So you are, really and truly, the fine travell'd young Gentleman, Mr. Flourish? Oh, you are a hopeful boy! I assure you, your father believes you have been seen and admir'd in every Court in Europe.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: So I ought to have been seen and admir'd in every Court in Europe, but I was unluckily introduc'd at the Court of King's Bench, and am not likely to visit any other Court in a hurry.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: You must contrive to be on terms with your father, to assist me in obtaining his sanction to my passion for his Ward, Miss Hartley.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: What! you have a passion for Miss Hartley? So have I too‚ÄîThat is unlucky.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: A passion for Miss Hartley?

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p: Yes: but I am by no means sure she has a passion for me: so, if you can prove she has for you, there are two to one against me.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: I'll lay the odds.

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p: Is it so? Enough said, then. He that can't make sport, never let him spoil it. 'Tis true, I had a liking for the young Lady, but the first principle of my liking was‚Äîto makeher happy; and as long as that is brought about, whether by you or me, is the same thing among friends. Ha! ha! ha! ha! my young Traveller, I can't help laughing to think that this very morning I was dusting the coat of a relation of your's.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: That was very kind of you; and while your hand is in, I'll thank you to dust mine‚Äîfor I'm sure it wants it.

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p: Farewel, my young Traveller‚Äîevery assistance I can give, you may depend on‚ÄîWell, Charles, you are a lucky dog to get such a sweet girl as Miss Hartley. Oh, the dear creatures, how I love them!

lg.l: IN the smiles of the fair
Is the best cure for care,
If ruffled our bosom, they charm it to ease;
Or with eye sweetly glancing,
Our hearts they set dancing,
They calm us and rouse us e'en just as they please.
The wise prop of a state,
Or the warrior so great,
Oft bows down to kiss Beauty's rod on his knees;
'Tis the province of Beauty
To teach men their duty,
For women can do with us just what they please.
E'en the miser quits gold,
Their bright charms to behold,
And gives them his soul, for he yields them his keys;
The dear rogues are so clever,
Oh! bless 'em for ever,
And may they rule over us just as they please.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Jack, I've been thinking how you are to get at liberty.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Have you? Well, how?

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Acquaint your father that you are return'd from abroad, then get a Rule for the day, and see him: his joy at the sight of you may soften his heart, and pave the way for your forgiveness.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Well said. I'll do it. I'll have a rule‚ÄîI'll hire a horse, as we call it.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Well, my boy, success attend you. All the assistance I can give you depend on. Farewel, my young Traveller! [Exit Harcourt.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p:
Damme, 'tis a lucky thought.‚ÄîAye, but they won't trust me out alone. I must take one of their watch dogs along with me. How shall I
manage that? I have it.‚ÄîYonder goes little Dicky. That's lucky! He's the man for my purpose. I must go to Monmouth-street myself, to brush up appearances, and so I'll take little Dicky with me, dress him smartly, and introduce him to my father as a Foreign Nobleman who came over with me.‚ÄîWell said.‚ÄîHuzza! Dicky! Dicky! I am so happy that I shall see the outside of that damn'd wall once more!

sp.speaker: DICKY.
sp.p: Do you vant me, Master Flourish?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Dicky, my boy, you are a clever little fellow; you are the only man that can serve me.

sp.speaker: DICKY.
sp.p: Vy, then, make it vorth my vhile, and nobody readier.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: I am going to have a Rule, hire a horse, as we call it, and you shall get up behind. There is nobody else in your way fit for a Gentleman's companion:‚ÄîYou are the only genteel article.

sp.speaker: DICKY.
sp.p: To be sure, they are damn'd wulgar.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: I am going to take you to my father's, and you must pass for a Man of Fashion.

sp.speaker: DICKY.
sp.p: Well, my Master, I'll try. I shall look it very well.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: No, no: I must put you on a lac'd coat.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.l: DICKY, I shall smartly dress you,

sp.speaker: DICKY.
sp.l: Vy, I'm smart enough, Lord bless you.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.l: No, no!

lg.l: Vy so?
Vat am I to pass for, pray?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.l: For a man of rank, I say.

lg.l: Vy then, dont I hit it quite?
Sure I'm drest exactly right.
Why really, Dicky, I must own
You're in the style of men of ton;
In side-boxes oft we view
Men of Fashion drest like you.
In side-boxes oft you see
Men of Fashion drest like me.
Very true,
Just like you,
But that will not with daddy do.

sp.speaker: DICKY
sp.l: Vy so?

lg.l: You must know
Dad's a bit of the old Beau,
And thinks it most becoming when
Men of Fashion dress like Gentlemen.
In side-boxes oft you see
Men of fashion drest like me.
Dad thinks it most becoming when
Men of Fashion dress like Gentlemen.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Young Testy's Chambers in the Temple. Young TESTY and SNARE at Breakfast.

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: And so you like London prodigiously?

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Hugely! What did my Quiz of a Father mean by keeping me in the Country so long? I ought to have been as wise as I am now five years ago.

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: To be sure; and your knowledge wou'd not have surpriz'd people either.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: No, not at all. I am not half so knowing as I ought to be, for all I was bred in Yorkshire.

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: That was in your favour.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p:
Oh! 'twas Heaven's mercy I was pitched into a cutish county, or I shou'd never have been
able to shew my face here. Why, boys of sixteen here know a great deal more than I do.

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: Boys of sixteen! Men of sixteen, you mean! Sixteen! why, 'tis the prime of a man's life! Who are your greatest men on the turf?‚Äîyour men of sixteen. Who keep your dashing women in the greatest style?‚Äîyour men of sixteen.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: So I thought. It came into my head, that keeping your dashing women was a very young trick.

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: Every thing now is in a state of forwardness unknown to our ancestors. London may be termed an immense hot house, where every thing is forc'd. You eat your fruit before it is in season. You run through your constitution before it is matured. You spend your estate before you are in possession, and get divorced from your wife before you ought to have married. 'Tis a lively system‚ÄîIs it not?

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Aye, a short life and a merry one.

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: But you were out of luck last night.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Yes, a little; and when I had lost all my money, it was vastly friendly of you to lend me the 200l. but I lost them too.

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: It will happen so sometimes. A lad of spirit does not mind such trifles. I will thank you, though, to return me the money: for I am rather out of cash.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Eh!

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: I'll thank you for the 200l. I lent you.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: My dear friend, I could as soon give you a million. My father does not allowance me in such a grand stile as that comes to. I must catch him in a devilish good humour, aye, and in a great many of them, before I get 200l. of him.

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: 'Tis damn'd shabby of you to borrow money you can't pay.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Is this your friendship? Why, did not you force it on me? Did not you tell me you only liv'd in obliging your friends?

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: You make a small mistake; I told you, I only liv'd by obliging my friends. But as it is not convenient to you to pay the money, give me your Note, and it will do just as well.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Ah! now you are my friend again. I thought you would not desert me so soon. You who so kindly took me by the hand‚Äîtaught me to punt at Faro, told me the nicks and crabs at Hazard, and though you never play yourself, were so kind to introduce me to all your friends that do.

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: Here's a stamp‚Äîsign your name‚ÄîI have fill'd it up. I thought you cou'dn't pay me directly.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: What is this?‚ÄîOn demand, I promise to pay Nic. Snare, Esq. 400l. value receiv'd.‚ÄîDang it, man, you lent me but two.

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: And do you think I'm to be paid nothing for my risk? Your father may disinherit you, and I may never get a doit. No, no, I shall never live by obliging my friends at that rate.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Oh, this is damn'd scandalous! pay four hundred pounds for two, and not have the worth of a six pence to show for it! Damn London‚ÄîI wish I had staid in Yorkshire all the days of my life.

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: It is very ungrateful of you to put yourself in a passion with me, who have taught you so many pretty games.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Yes, and you want to teach me another pretty game‚Äîto shew me that One and One make Four.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: [Without.] Tom! Let me in.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Zounds, my father! I must open the door.

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: [Laying hold of him.] No, you shan't till you have settled our business.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Tom, I say, let me in.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Coming, Sir.

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: If you don't sign, I'll tell him all your pranks.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: [Signs] There, and the devil do you good with it. Damn Gaming‚Äîdamn Swindling‚Äîand damn‚Äî [Opens the door.] How do you do, Sir.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: How do I do? You made great haste to ask me! Why, you have company. Is this the way you pass your mornings? You ought to be at study, Sir.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: This Gentleman comes to assist me in my studies, Sir.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Oh! that is very kind of him. Thank you, Sir, for all you have taught my son.

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: O, Sir, 'tis a pleasure to me.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Do you practise much at the bar, Sir?

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: Not much now, Sir. I have had in my time a pretty deal of Old Baily practice.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: And retir'd from it with your just deserts?

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: Not exactly, Sir, or I must say I should have been in a more elevated situation. Men often retire from the Bar with less than they merit.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p:
More's the pity. Well‚ÄîI will not intrude any longer, Tom. I call'd to give you money
to pay for your furniture and your books: never be in debt longer than you can help. Always pay your way. There's a draft for 400l. and so good morning, and thank you kindly for all you have done for my son. [Exit.

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: A very good kind of an old gentleman that father of your's: mind what he says‚Äî"Never be in debt longer than you can help. Always pay your way." That 400l. will just balance our little account.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Why, you an't such a rogue?

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: You had better be correct in your language, young Gentleman, or you must satisfy my honour.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Oh, damn your honour! Did not you hear my father say, it was for my Upholsterer and Bookseller? They have been for their money already, and if I don't pay them, who knows but they will send me to jail?

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: Oh no! Tradesmen are us'd to go without their money; but Gentlemen, like me, must touch the ready, or your character is lost for ever. So at once pay me, or I'll expose you.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: There‚Äîplague take you‚Äîthere is the money. And now if I don't marry directly, I may go hang myself; and of two evils‚Äî

sp.speaker: SNARE.
sp.p: Marry, by all means. Good-bye, Tom. Remember, I live by obliging my friends! [Exit.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: The devil fly away with such friends! Oh, I'm in a pretty mess! If Miss Hartley hadn't taken such a fancy to me, what wou'd have become of me! 'Tis Heaven's mercy I was a likely lad!‚ÄîMy beauty has sav'd my bacon. I'm in a fine way‚ÄîI shall certainly be arrested‚ÄîI can't save my liberty, that is certain. All I can do is to try to lose it my own way. Of the two, 'tis better to marry than go to jail; but at whose suit I shall be obliged to surrender myself, my Wife's, or my Tradesmen's, depends entirely on whether the Bailiff, or the Parson does his business quickest. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Lady Flourish's Dressing-Room. A Sopha, and Sash Window with Curtains. KITTY discover'd.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Well, thank my stars, I shan't long be oblig'd to do such menial business! Call'd here, and call'd there‚ÄîNo, no, I shall soon be young Mr. Testy's wife; and then Madam Testy will call her servants about her as haughtily as the first Lady in the land.

lg.l: WHAT a hard lot is ours now, indeed and indeed,
'Tis a terrible life that we poor servants lead,
Up early and late,
To toil and to wait,
To do as one's bid,
Yet for ever be chid‚ñ™
Ill humours to bear,
And yet not to dare,
Tho' with anger we burn,
To be spiteful and cross in return.
What a hard lot is ours then, indeed and indeed,
'Tis a terrible life that we poor servants lead.
To be sure, when one happens a service to get in,
Where, to aid Madam's frolics, her secrets we're let in,
Why then, I must own, of our blabbing afraid,
The maid is the mistress, the mistress the maid.
They coax one so pretty,
'Tis "dear Mrs. Kitty!
You're so kind and clever,
I'll love you for ever."
Our wages they double,
Yet give us no trouble,
And, while they're so civil,
We're as saucy and pert as the devil.
What a hard lot is theirs then, indeed and indeed,
'Tis a terrible life our poor Mistresses lead!
But the times are so alter'd, these places are rare now,
For who knows their intrigues, there are few ladies care now,
A faux-pas to conceal they will use little labour,
Whilst each lady's in countenance kept by her neighbour.
Their spouses so kind too,
Such foibles are blind to,
Nay, some will assume our vocation;
If a go-between's needed,
We're pass'd by unheeded,
The husband takes our occupation.
What a strange lot is theirs then! indeed and indeed‚ñ™
'Tis a whimsical life that some husbands lead.

div.p: Dear me, here comes my papa that is to be.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: What! I have found somebody at last: I have been hunting from room to room, and the devil a soul cou'd I see.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Sir, my Master and Mistress are not at home.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Since I can't prove to the contrary, I incline to believe so.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let me show you out. You have intruded yourself into my Lady's dressingroom.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Don't hurry me, you young baggage‚Äîand pray who are you with that pretty face?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Your daughter that is to be. (Aside.) I am Kitty, Sir.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Kitty, you are a pretty girl. Give me a kiss, Kitty.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, don't be rumbustical!

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: I say, Kitty‚Äîthis is what I have wanted a long while. (Aside.) I say, Kitty, do you like your place? Shou'd you have any objection to quit it, to live with a middle-aged gentleman as a kind of a Housekeeper, eh?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, I hope you have no design upon my Honour! [With affected delicacy.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: No, not I‚ÄîI dare say your honour has been long out of the way of any body's design‚ÄîBut tell me, cou'd you like such a plain-spoken, comely-looking matter-of-fact-man as myself, eh?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: This is lucky. I'll humour the old fellow, and when I marry his son, he'll not be angry with me, for fear of my exposing him.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Well, what do you say, my pretty?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: I don't know what to say, Sir.‚ÄîIf I cou'd have it under your hand that you woudn't forsake me‚Äî

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Under my hand‚Äîhum!‚ÄîDamn it, there is no making love now without signing and sealing. A love-letter will be sent back unopen'd, unless 'tis on stamp'd paper; and Cupid himself wou'd not be half so good a go between as a common Attorney.

lg.l: WOMAN now by grace and feature,
Sighs and vows, will not be caught,
If you'd have the pretty creature,
The pretty creature must be bought.
You may swear,
You may tear,
You may cry,
You may lie,
You may kneel,
You may feel
All the pangs that from love's raging fervours arise.
And proclaim her an angel dropt down from the skies.
No pity she shews
For your budget of woes;
She scoffs at your tears, and derides all your pain,
And e'en darling flatt'ry assails her in vain.
Who then finds the way
His addresses to pay,
In a style which this whimsical creature can fix;
He who drives to her door
In a chariot and four,
Or old Nick himself in a fine coach and six.

sp.p: Well, what am I to give you under my hand?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Only your promise that you love me, and won't forsake me.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Come, there is no great harm in a promise without a penalty. (Aside.)‚Äî [Takes out his Pocket-book and writes on a leaf.] There, there's my written promise, and now, my pretty dear‚Äî (Going to kiss her.)

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH,
sp.p: (Without.) Kitty! is your Lady come home, Kitty?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Oh dear me, here is Sir Simon! What shall I do? Coming, Sir. I woudn't have him see you and me alone together, for the world.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Nor I neither. The rascal wou'd banter me to death.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: And I shou'd lose my character. Oh, dear Sir, hide yourself.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Where? where?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Any where, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Kitty!

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Coming, Sir‚Äîthere, under the sopha, Sir.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Zounds! I shall be cramp'd to death.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Kitty, I say.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Make haste, make haste.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Well, if I must, I must. (Gets under the sopha.) Send him away directly.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, yes.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Why, Kitty, what are you in such a bustle about? My Lady is not at home, is she?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: No, Sir, no.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: I'm glad of it. I came home on purpose to catch you alone, Kitty.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Oh ho! you did, did you? (From under the sopha.)

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: You are the prettiest little rogue in the world, Kitty. You know how long I have been in love with you, Kitty; now, do have compassion on me!

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, be quiet, and don't take such liberties.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Why, my dear, charming Kitty.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: (Without.) Pray, Captain O Neil, do me the kindness to walk this way.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: My Lady's voice!

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: By all that's discordant! She must not see me here with you. I told her I should not be at home till night. She'll suspect something.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Well she may, if she sees me in this rumpl'd condition. Oh dear, what shall I do? where shall I run?

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Here here,‚Äîcome, quick.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Oh dear! oh dear!

div.stage: Enter Lady FLOURISH and Captain O'NEIL.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: This way, Captain O'Neil. Allow me to shew you into my little dressing-room.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Your Ladyship does me great honour.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: Pray, sit down. I conducted you here, Captain O'Neil, that I might not be agitated again by Sir Simon's intrusion.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Vastly well.

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p: Mada the reason of my calling now is‚Äî

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: I know your reasons very well, you can't impose on me, though you have on my husband.

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p: My dear Lady, I wish to be understood.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: I don't in the least doubt it: but gentlemen of your country, with the best intentions in the world, sometimes ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nd it a very difficult matter. But I understand you perfectly; the passion you ventur'd to intimate this morning‚Äî

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p: I have, now, my Lady, entirely relinquish'd‚Äî

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: What! you barbarous man, have you ensnared my susceptible heart, and do you now abandon your conquest?

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p: I ensnare your susceptible heart!

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: Yes, you inhuman creature!‚ÄîOh! Oh! (crying) 'Tis too much, too much to bear!

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: (Rushing from behind the curtain.) 'Tis too much for me to bear. To hear one's wife make love to another man, is too much for anybody to bear!

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p: Sir Simon!

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: Sir Simon!

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Yes, the wrong'd Sir Simon.‚ÄîIs this the way you reward my faithful love, my fond attachment? [Lady Flourish sinks on the sopha, fainting.

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p: Get her a little water, Sir Simon:‚ÄîI'll give her some air. [Going towards the window.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Don't give her any air, she'll be better without it.
sp.stage: [Captain O'Neil runs to open the window, throws aside the curtains, and discovers Kitty: She screams, which calls the attention of Lady Flourish.]

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: Very well, Sir Simon! This is your faithful love‚Äîyour fond attachment!

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p: Oh, the blessing of mutual affection! These are the fond turtle-doves.‚ÄîFaith you are well pair'd.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: I shall never recover this terrible shock!

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p: Now the impediment is remov'd, let me recommend a little ventilation to your Ladyship. (Opens the window.) Pray sit, and enjoy it as comfortably as you can (Runs to the sopha, and draws it back towards the window, by which Old Testy is discovered) What have we got here! It looks like a great turtle, left on the shore by the retiring of the tide. (Pointing to Lady Flourish and Kitty.) Favour me with one of your fins. (Raising him up by the arm.)

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Mr. Testy, what the devil do you do here?

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.p: Mr. Testy, what is your business in my dressing-room?

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Your dressing-room is a place of wonderful business indeed!

sp.speaker: CAPT. O'NEIL.
sp.p: Pray, to which party do you belong?

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Which party! You see I am out now; and, what is not uncommon, I kept my place as long as I cou'd.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: What do you mean by your outs and ins in my house? I have a great mind to make an example of you. To be found under the sopha, in my wife's dressing-room! Why, the Bank of England could hardly pay the damages a liberal crim. con. Jury would give me.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.l: I'LL teach you to play the antic:

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.l: So you can, for you know how.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.l: They will surely drive me frantic.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.l: I am innocent, I vow.

lg.l: O be quiet!
Make no riot.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.l: Make no riot! but I will.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.l: You've forgot.

lg.l: No, I've not;
No, with you I'm very still.
Come, agree,
For I see
You had all the self-same plan,
All but the modest Irishman.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.l: For no good he came, 'tis certain.

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.l: I know nothing why he came;

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.l: Why went you behind the curtain?

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.l: Ah, Sir Simon, blush for shame!

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.l: Oh, the curtain!

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.l: Pretty flirting;

lg.l: True, my tender, darling wife,
Constant dove!

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.l: Faithful love!

lg.l: Psha! leave off this foolish strife,
For you had all the self-same plan.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.l: But me and the modest Irishman.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.l: Ma'am, forgive me;

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.l: That I'll never.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.l: Don't forget your freaks are known:

sp.speaker: LADY FLOURISH.
sp.l: Character you've lost for ever:

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.l: Pray, my lady, where's your own?

lg.l: I don't heed it,
Servants need it,
Ladies do as well without.
Come, give o'er,
Talk no more,
Why keep up this foolish rout,
When you had all the self-same plan?
But me and the modest Irishman.
But me
Suspicions certainly appear,
But I'm in my conscience clear,
And therefore nothing have to fear;
For you had all the self-same plan,
But me and the modest Irishman.
'Tis quite shocking,
You're but mocking,
You to innocence pretend!
You're found out,
Past a doubt:
Cease your folly to defend;
For you had all the self-same plan,
But me and the modest Irishman.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: A Garden. HARCOURT and HARRIOT discovered.

lg.l: TELL me, my love, wou'd'st thou forego
Transports, which only lovers know‚Äî
To heal at once the poignant smart
That still must rack the anxious heart;
Trembling, lest all its scheme of joy
Fortune for ever shou'd destroy.
Ah no! the throbbings of delight,
Which in each pulse proclaim thy sight,
The bounding heart's tumultuous beat,
Swelling its kindred heart to meet,
Are joys for which all pain I'd prove,
And never, never cease to love.

sp.speaker: HARRIOT.
sp.p: Here comes Sir Simon. Heavens! how shall I account for your being here?

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Don't be alarm'd, my love; I'll think of some excuse. [They turn up the Stage.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p:
Eh! who have we here? a young man tete a tete with my Ward! Well done; it runs through the family; I'll be bound there isn't an unpair'd turtle in my whole establishment. This is a worse business than my wife's a great deal, for this young lady will wish to carry her fortune
as well as her inclinations, out of my family. Now, though my wife may send her affections on a visit, I still keep at home all I married her for. (Harcourt and Miss Hartley come forward.) Pray, Miss Hartley, have I the honour of knowing this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: MISS HARTLEY.
sp.p: The Gentleman, Sir, has business with you.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Sir, your son, who is my particular friend, both of the same College, has commissioned me to acquaint you of his safe arrival in England.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: My boy arrived! Huzza! Sir, I shall be proud of your acquaintance. How soon may I expect to see my son?

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Very shortly, Sir. I got the start of him, and hasten'd to make you happy with this intelligence.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: How far have you been travelling, Sir?

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Just as far as your son, Sir Simon?

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Well, Sir, and how do you like foreign parts?

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Ah! Sir, I believe Travellers, who have seen more of foreign countries than I have, will give the palm to Old England.

lg.l: THY glory in war let those loudly proclaim,
Who mistake discord's blast for the trumpet of fame,
And give slaughter the meed of renown;
'Tis, Britain, thy praise,
The sword ne'er to raise
In ravage and plunder's fell cause;
But to guard sacred honour's pure laws,
And the pride of the base to bring down.
Still o'er the fall'n foe
Let pity's tear flow,
Not sound forth the triumph of blood.
No, Britain, thou art great and good;
Let this thy glory be,
This let admiring nations see,
That with thee
Dwells sweet Humanity.

div.p: Sir, I must now take my leave.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Won't you stay till your friend arrives?

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Now, Sir Simon, I am particularly engaged; but I shall hope for the pleasure of being further known to you.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: You honour me very much, Sir, and a thousand thanks for your kind visit. [Exit Harcourt.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: (Alone.) My son return'd, and so soon to see him! This atones for all my disasters. The sight of my accomplish'd boy will almost compensate for the loss of being Second in a Duel to an Irishman; will almost make me forget the hearty threshing he gave me, and my wife's making love to him. These are misfortunes, to be sure‚Äîbut Jack is come home, and I will think no more of them. [Exit.

sp.speaker: HARRIOT.
sp.p: I will endeavour to repress every anxious thought, and dwell only on the prospect of future happiness.

lg.l: COME, smiling Hope, dispel each chilling fear,
And with thy glowing beams my bosom cheer;
On future blessings dart thy vivid ray,
Chasing the low'ring clouds of doubt away;
To bright perspective still direct my eye,
And cast in shade the blightest objects nigh.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: A Street. Enter BLUFF, the Bailiff, and Followers.

sp.speaker: BLUFF.
sp.p: Are you sure, Tom, you dogg'd the right man?

sp.speaker: 1st. FOLLOWER.
sp.p: Quite sure, Master Bluff.

sp.speaker: BLUFF.
sp.p: And why didn't you take him?

sp.speaker: 1st. FOLLOWER.
sp.p: Because he got into church before I could get at him.

sp.speaker: BLUFF.
sp.p: And so I am to be kept waiting here till he chuses to come out of church? Oh, here he comes.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Well, the job is done; I'm a married man for the first time in my life. 'Tis devilish comical. I wonder how I shall like it! Mrs. Testy, how do you do, my dear?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: How do you do, Tom?

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Tom! I don't know whether I like to be call'd Tom now. It don't shew respect enough from a Wife to her Husband.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Respect from a Wife to a Husband! O Tom! your Country Education! I see you will be very troublesome to me.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: I don't know whether I shall be troublesome or no. Dang it, one can't begin too soon to shew one is determin'd to wear the breeches. (Aside.) Mrs. Testy, I desire you will consider what is due to a Husband.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: And I desire, Mr. Testy, you will consider what is due to a Wife.

sp.speaker: BLUFF.
sp.p: And I desire, Mr Testy, you will consider what is due to a Creditor. (Taps him on the sh ulder.) I am sorry, good folks, to interrupt your nuptial harmony. Here's a little bit of a writ against you.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
