sp.p: At whose suit?

sp.speaker: BLUFF.
sp.p: Your Bookseller's.

sp.speaker: 1st. FOLLOWER.
sp.p: And here's another.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: At whose suit?

sp.speaker: 1st. FOLLOWER.
sp.p: Your Upholsterer's.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Writs against my dearly beloved? How soon the comforts of matrimony begin!

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Well, I don't mind; when I touch my wife's fortune I shall be at liberty directly.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Your debts must be very small, if your wife's fortune will pay them. [Aside.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Where must I go

sp.speaker: BLUFF.
sp.p: That depends on how much of the ready you have got.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Damn it, they are all for the ready. I say, wife‚Äîmy dear‚Äî

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: (Sulkily.) What do you want?

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Have you got any of the ready?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: No, not I.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Have n't you, indeed!‚Äîsearch.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: I have nothing but two pocket pieces and a silver bodkin.

sp.speaker: BLUFF.
sp.p:
Come, come, poor as a rat‚ÄîI see you
must go to prison directly; I have no room for such paupers as you: so come along.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: My darling‚Äîand must I be torn from my loving wife? [Sobbing.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Oh, dear! Oh, dear! 'tis very distressing.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Bless my soul, who is that coming yonder‚ÄîSure, 'tis Jack Flourish; it is‚ÄîStand back a little.

div.stage: Enter Young FLOURISH and DICKY, both dressed in Monmouth-street Finery.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Here I am once more at large in London streets. What a luxury it is again to be jostled about, and nearly run over by the coaches and carts! Lord, how happy I am to be out of that damn'd cage, though only for a day! Dicky, you look vastly well.

sp.speaker: DICKY.
sp.p: Yes, my master, good clothes become me.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: As I was obliged to have a jailor to attend me‚ñ™ it is lucky, Dicky, I cou'd get one so much of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: DICKY.
sp.p: It wou'd be damn'd hard if I cou'd not behave like a gemman, who have liv'd all my life in gemmen's company, in the King's Bench, and the Marshalsea, and the Debtors Side of Newgate.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p:
Yes, Dicky, 'tis certainly very genteel to be intimate in those places; but, you know, one shou'd not brag of one's connections: so mum's the word before my father; I must pass you
off for a Foreign Count; so mind your hits, Dicky.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Ecod, I'll speak to him. Don't let him see your face. Do you walk a little that way; (to Kitty (for as I am going to ask a favour of him, it might not be so prudent to let him know I have married his Mistress.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Lord! you fool, many a gentleman would be much oblig'd to you for marrying his Mistress.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: I say, Jack‚ÄîJack Flourish‚Äî

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Eh!

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: What, don't you know me? I know you, you see, for all your outlandish clothes.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: What, Tom Testy?

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Yes, I be Tom Testy.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: I am devilish glad to see you.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Be you indeed! that's right. 'Tis lucky to meet friends when one wants them, is it not? One should never be shy of a friend when he is in trouble, shou'd one?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: No, to be sure not. What the devil does he mean? [Aside.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: If I was to meet a friend with a Bailiff at his elbow‚Äî (Flourish turns and looks at Dicky) I should be as glad to see him as if I met him walking with a Nobleman.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Bailiff and Nobleman! Yes, yes, he twigs me. He knows Dicky here in his real and masquerade character both. [Aside.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: I say, I should be as happy to shake hands with him at one time as another.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: And so should I, upon my soul. (Shaking hands.) O damn it, all's up‚ÄîI am found out‚Äî [Aside.] I say, Tom‚ÄîI see how the thing is‚ÄîHow the devil came you to know it?

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Know it! dang it, I could not help knowing it; for before he said a word, he gave me such a cursed thump on the shoulder‚ñ™ as nobody would have ventur'd to have done that hadn't the law to back him.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Eh! [Looking about and seeing Bluff.

sp.speaker: BLUFF.
sp.p: Come, come, I an't to stay here a whole Term arresting you. Will the Gemman bail you or not?

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Aye, Jack, will you bail me?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: I bail!‚ÄîI bail you! Here's an affair! What. Tom, you arrested?‚Äîha! ha! well said, young Rural.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Don't laugh! don't laugh, Jack‚ÄîWhat will you do for me?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: I can't bail you, I'm not an housekeeper. But where are you going?

sp.speaker: YOUNC TESTY.
sp.p: [To Bluff.] Ay, where am I going?

sp.speaker: BLUFF.
sp.p: Straight to the King's Bench.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: The King's Bench‚Äîthat's unlucky- [Aside.] for then we shall know more of one another than I wish. I say, Tom‚ñ™ Newgate is a very pretty prison. You had better go to Newgate.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Newgate! Don't mention it.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Well, there is no persuading people to their good against their inclination. If you will go to the King's Bench, I will certainly come and see you there.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Will you be so kind?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: I will, upon my soul

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: It is vastly good natur'd of you.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Not at all. It won't be putting me out of my way in the least.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: It is your good-nature makes you say so.‚ÄîGood-bye, Jack; we shall meet again soon, then.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Yes, Tom, much sooner than I wish. [Aside.] Farewel.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Good-bye, you'll not forget to come.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: No, not I: but if I should, here is a Gentleman will remind me.

sp.speaker: BLUFF.
sp.p: Take care of him. [To one of his Followers, who exit with Young Testy.] Now how stand our other jobs?

lg.l: JEMMY Chimer, the rhymer, from his garret I hawl'd,
By Sir Thunder O'Blunder I was cursedly maul'd;
For young Stakeall of Rakehall I was sent on the scout,
So I sought him and caught him at Lady Plunder's rout.
Blessing on those gaming-houses!
Oh, the th ‚Ä¢ ught our spirits rouses,
They're the cause of our well-doing,
They draw in ten flats to ruin.
Charming Faro!
Game so rare O!
Fleece away, ye dames of style,
Fill your purses,
Laugh at curses,
Bailiffs bless you all the while.

sp.speaker: 1st.
sp.l: I've a writ for Colonel Spendall,

sp.speaker: 2d.
sp.l: I have one for Doctor Endall,

sp.speaker: 3d.
sp.l: And I one for Simon Lendall.

lg.l: Bravo! Nab 'em, have 'em tight.
Merry then we'll be at night;
These will yield a jovial quaff
To us Officers o' th' staff.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Sir Simon's House. Enter Sir SIMON and Old TESTY.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: I am surpriz'd you have the assurance to enter my doors again. Where the devil are you come to hide yourself now? There is no sopha here for you: but you may get up the chimney if you will.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Pshaw! I am come on business: you'll, may be, like worse your darling Boy‚ÄîYour accomplish'd Traveller is not far off.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: I know it.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: You know it, do you? What, you know he is in the King's Bench?

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: What do you say?

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: In Banco ‚Ä¢ egis.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: What the devil should he do in the King's Bench. He is just arrived from abroad, and I shall see him in a few minutes.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p:
In a few minutes! So you may, but you must gallop to St. George's Fields, then‚Äîha! ha! ha! the all-accomplish'd youth that has been getting the finishing stroke to his fashionable education! Well, you have not been much
out‚Äîit is the finishing stroke to many a fashionable education.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: What is come to the man! That damn'd sopha you crept under, has cramp'd your faculties as well as your limbs. Don't tease me with your nonsense.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH,
sp.p: [Without.] Par ici, Monsieur le Comte.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: There, there, what dy'e say now? My son is in the King's Bench, is he?

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Why here he is faith, and I've been told a damn'd lie then.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: My dear, dear Jack, come to my arms.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Ah! mon Pere, comment vous portez vous? O mon Dieu! I had forgot‚ÄîI must speak English now.‚ÄîHow do you do, father?

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: What, forgot your English, boy?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: 'Tis so long since I have spoken it, that it is as aukward to me, as the acknowledgment of an old friend to a man who has got sudden promotion. Well, father, how do you do?

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Happy to see you, my boy.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Bien oblige‚ÄîDamn it, there I go again.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Never mind, Jack, it shews your breeding.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Ah! Testy! how are you, my old boy?

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: La! la!‚ÄîThere's French for you, puppy.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: As sulky as ever, eh! (Slapping him on the shoulder.) Why don't you travel and polish a bit, my old Buck?

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Polish a bit, my old Buck! Don't be so damn'd familiar, or I shall try whether my cane can't polish a bit my young Buck.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: What a sour old Crab it is, father. Permittez moi a vous‚Äî (Stopping himself.) Psha! that is, permit me to introduce to you my friend and companion, Count Tipstaffo Kingsbencheni.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Those damn'd foreign names‚ÄîI never cou'd learn one of them.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: I am the Count's most obsequious humble servant.

sp.speaker: DICKY.
sp.p: Vy, my Master, for matter of that‚Äî

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Silence, you dog, or you'll ruin me. The Count speaks little English‚ÄîHush!

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Well, my boy, tell me where have you been.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: You'll know all in good time, father: to tell you at once where I have been, would surprise you too much.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Really!

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: It wou'd, upon my honour.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: What, then, you have been further than you expected to go?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Not further. I have been where I did not expect to go.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Now the old doting fool will swallow all his lies for gospel.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Well, Jack, come tell me all about it. I say, are the women very pretty abroad?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: If I had not found them so pretty at home, I might have been able to tell you. (Aside) The women, Sir, are, to be sure, very handsome; but leaving England to seek Beauty, is like going abroad to look for Liberty. The prime commodities are in our own market.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Well, Jack, in what Court did you chiefly reside?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: In what Court?‚ÄîWhy, where I chiefly resided was not exactly a Court; but it belong'd to one.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: And so, my son liv'd in a palace?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Yes, yes, a kind of a palace‚Äîlarge enough of all conscience: rooms rather shabby, though‚Äînot kept neat‚Äîand surrounded by a damn'd high wall.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Aye, for fear people shou'd get in.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: No, for fear people shou'd get out.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: What, so afraid to part with you?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Oh! very much‚ÄîOnce I have the honour to get in, 'tis devilish hard to get out again.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Now, in my mind, that is carrying civility too far.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: But how is my mother-in-law, Lady Flourish, eh? why you look glum, Father; has any thing happened?

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: O! nothing, but what is so common now-a-days, that 'tis quite a folly to think about it. But I am very rude to pay so little attention to your friend the Count. Sir, wou'd you be pleased to take some refreshment?

sp.speaker: DICKY.
sp.p: I thanks your Honour, nothing at all: I took a drap of gin as I came along.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Oh! curse you, you stupid dog.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: A drap of gin!

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: 'Tis a strange liqueur for a foreign nobleman! The Count speaks English pretty fluently, though rather queerly.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Yes, yes, he don't speak much; but the little he does, he speaks like a native.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Yes, like a native of Broad St. Giles's.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p:
Don't let him hear you: h'ell be offended,
and he is a damn'd fighting little fellow, when he is provok'd.

div.stage: Enter Servant, and gives a Letter to Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH,
sp.p: (Opens it.) It looks like a woman's hand. (Reads.) This comes to desire you to tell Mr. Testy, that his son is in the King's Bench. This is from one who is much concern'd in his welfare. Why, Testy, you find there is a little bit of a mistake. 'Tis your son, not mine, that is in the King's Bench‚Äîha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: I don't know whether I am awake, or asleep, alive or dead.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! he would have it you were in the King's Bench.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: (Confus'd, and endeavouring to overcome it by assum'd gaiety) I in the King's Bench! yes! I look vastly as if I had been in the King's Bench‚Äîha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: (Laugh at Testy) Ha, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: It can't be. 'Tis out of all human possibility.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: You may soon be convinc d; you may see him in a few minutes‚Äîbut you must gallop to St. George's Fields, then‚Äîha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: I'll go directly, and if I find him there, I'll disinherit him; and I'll adopt‚Äîdamme‚ÄîI'll adopt one of the Catabaw Indians.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: We will go along with you.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Come then, call a coach there‚ÄîI'm mad‚Äîstark mad. [Exit Old Testy.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Won't you go; Jack?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: What, to the King's Bench? I wonder what kind of a place it can be. I have a great mind to go out of curiosity. What do you say, Count? Will you go by way of a lounge?
sp.stage: [Dicky going to speak, Young Flourish stops him.]
sp.p: You need not speak, the Count nods assent.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Aye, it will be a new sight to the Count.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Not very. (Aside.) Come, Dicky, for go we must, you know.

sp.speaker: DICKY.
sp.p: Aye, aye, returnable‚Äînolens, volens.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Hush! yes, yes, the Count and I will go with you, and see this queer kind of a place. What do you stop for, father?

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: To let the Count go first.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Aye, by all means. I beg the Count's pardon.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: An Apartment in the King's Bench; KITTY and Young TESTY, with the Keeper, discovered.

sp.speaker: KEEPER.
sp.p: Though the prison is so full, you have got as good as a room to yourselves, for there is only one gentleman belongs to it.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: One gentleman belongs to it!

sp.speaker: KEEPER.
sp.p: Yes. He is gone out on a Day Rule, but he must be home soon; he'll be pleasant company for you and the Lady.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Yes, very! 'Tis devilish pleasant to have a gentleman sleep in the room with one's wife.

sp.speaker: KEEPER.
sp.p: It may be a little awkward to the Lady at first, but she'll soon come into it.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY,
sp.p: (Without.) Where is this ungracious villain?

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Oh lord! Oh lord! here's my father. Hide yourself, hide yourself, (to Kitty, who conceals herself behind one of the beds.) Now I shall have it sweetly.

div.stage: Enter Old TESTY, Sir SIMON, and Young FLOURISH.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Let me come to the rascal‚Äî (they hold him.) Why, you graceless wretch, what have you to say for yourself?

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Lord, father, you have come upon me in such a hurry, I have not settled what I have to say for myself.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: They have lodg'd him in my room, by Jupiter. [Aside.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: You to turn out profligate and extravagant, when I took such care to the contrary! Didn't I breed you out of the way of all manner of harm!

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Yes, and therefore not knowing it, when he saw it, how was he able to avoid it?

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Aye, how was I able to avoid it?

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Till you came to London, did you know what it was to have more than six-pence in your pocket?

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Then how the devil did you expect him to know the value of guineas, when you trusted him with them?

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, will you?

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Didn't I always tell you how foolish you were to bring him up in that ridiculous way. I knew my plan was the best, was it not, my boy?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Oh certainly, father; no doubt about it.

sp.speaker: KEEPER.
sp.p: Oh, here's Master Flourish come home.‚ÄîPray, Master Flourish‚Äî
sp.stage: (Young Flourish makes signs to him to hold his tongue.]

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Master Flourish come home! Why, how the devil does he know you?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: (Crossing over to the Keeper.) Ah! what, Bobby, is it you?‚ÄîHold your tongue you, dog‚ÄîOh! I knew Bobby abroad! Bobby was head jailer to the Emperor of Morocco. Ah! Bobby! how do you do, Bobby‚Äîhow long have you been in England, Bobby?

sp.speaker: KEEPER.
sp.p: How long have I‚Äî

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: (Putting his hand to his mouth, and drawing him aside.) I want to talk with you, Bobby, about the Emperor's two daughters, Boblatilda and Gruntawiska. Come this way‚ÄîExcuse me (To Sir Simon.) I have some secrets to talk to Bobby about. (They go up the stage.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Well, you rascal, what can you say for yourself, you stupid dolt?

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Why father, if I have been a stupid dolt one way, I have been pretty cunning another. I was cheated out of my money, to be sure, but I have cheated other people out of a Wife.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: A Wife! What does the blockhead mean?

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Not such a blockhead as you think.‚ñ™Suppose now, I should have married Miss Hartley, all out of my own head, without any of your help?

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY AND SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Married Miss Hartley!

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p:
Aye, married Miss Hartley‚ñ™ and suppose she
shou'd like me well enough to follow me to prison.

div.stage: Enter Miss HARTLEY, HARCOURT, and O'NEIL.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Prodigious!

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Nothing but my own eyes cou'd have convinc'd me.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Come to my arms. All is forgiven. You are a clever boy. I did not think it had been in you. Eh! Simon, what do you think of my boy now?

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: I am petri≈øied!

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Huzza! huzza! Yorkshire for ever!‚ÄîHuzza!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: I am glad to find you so merry; we heard you were come here, and thinking a friend of our's might be in a little hobble, we came to intercede.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: There needs no intercession; 'tis all right‚Äî'tis all as it shou'd be, my dear girl. (To Miss Hartley) We have heard of your marriage. Take him, take him, take your husband.

sp.speaker: MISS HARTLEY.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Nay, don't be shame-fac'd; it is all known; 'tis all forgiv'n.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: All known! all forgiv'n! Generous conduct! our mutual affection made us overlook every other consideration, and marriage has now ratified the union of our hearts.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: What is all this?

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Why, Tom, what the devil, has your wife married another husband so soon?

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Why what the devil right have you to marry Tom's wife?

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: My wife! that is a good one. I believe they are all mad. I never saw that fine Lady in my life.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: You didn't? And all you have been telling me about your marriage is a damn'd lie then‚ÄîLet me come at him. [They hold him.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Will you be quiet, father, and hear a little reason? I tell you I married Miss Hartley, and you shall have her own word for it. Mrs. Testy! Mrs. Testy!

div.p: There, what do you say now? There's my wife!

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: The devil it is!

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: Why, what the devil do you all laugh at?

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Only at a little error in your politics My rural Machiavel, instead of the Mistress, you have married the Maid!

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: It is very true, husband.

sp.speaker: YOUNG TESTY.
sp.p: The devil it is!

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Wiseacre, you have married all out of your own head, without my help, and now you may keep your precious bargain without my help. You may starve, you may rot in a prison, for you shall never have sixpence from me.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, how can you be so unkind! You didn't look so cross at me the last time I saw you.

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Eh! what?

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: Don't you remember, how good-humour'd you look'd just before you got under the sopha.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Oh! now the murder is out. I say, Testy, you had better give hush-money, for if we old fellows let the girls tell all they know about us, it may not be for our credit: besides, the world may be spiteful enough to say you are angry with your son, because you wanted to marry the girl yourself.

sp.speaker: KITTY.
sp.p: I don't know, Sir, as to marrying, but I have a little bit of paper here, which‚Äî

sp.speaker: OLD TESTY.
sp.p: Hold your tongue‚ÄîSay no more. I believe you are quite good enough for the blockhead you have got, and so he may pack into Yorkshire again, and carry you with him as a sample of a London Fine Lady.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: But this gentleman's taking the liberty of marrying our Ward without our consent is a thing which‚Äî

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Oh! 'tis a very great insult‚Äîand a word in your ear, my little game-cock‚ÄîIf you mean to call him to account for it, I'll be your Second.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: I don't want to have any thing to do with Seconds.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: When I was going to fight him, you were to have been my Second, and I only offer to return the obligation.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: What, is this the gentleman you redeem'd out of prison, to have the pleasure of fighting?

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Is it to you, then, I owe my liberty? Generous man!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Oh, it was very generous, to be sure, to release you out of prison, that I might have the satisfaction of sending you out of the world. But Sir Simon, this gentleman, in fortune, is equal to the Lady he has wedded.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Captain O'Neil, I am not conscious of what you are asserting.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p:
But I am, or I wou'd not assert it. Understanding that your Uncle had taken it into his head to be angry with you for nothing at all, I called on the old gentleman to talk with him a little about it‚Äî"If your Nephew had been
guilty of a dishonourable action," said I, "devil a word wou'd O'Neil offer in his behalf; but as he has been a dupe to the villainy of others, restore him to your favour, and launch him into the world again, with experience for his Pilot."‚ÄîSo the old gentleman shook hands with me, and swore he was ready to do the same with you as soon as you pleased.

sp.speaker: HARCOURT.
sp.p: Thanks are too poor for such nobleness of soul!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Nobleness of soul! for walking a few steps out of my common road, for the pleasure of reconciling a discarded Nephew to a rich old Uncle. Oh! if people wou'd but just lengthen their morning's walk to do a few good natur'd actions, they can scarcely conceive what health and spirits such exercise wou'd give them, and how much sweeter they wou'd rest for it at night!

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Harcourt, I give you joy.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Give him joy‚Äîwhy, you part with your Mistress very easily.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: 'Tis the fashion, father.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Well, I think we may all adjourn, we have staid in this dismal place long enough.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: I have for one, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Then let us be gone directly.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: That is sooner said than done.

sp.speaker: DICKY.
sp.p: Master Flourish, here is the man, from Monmouth Street. He knows you are come home, and he must and will have his cloaths. He has got mine.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Must have his cloaths‚ÄîKnows you are come home! Why, that is the Count. I smell powder.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: And that is a scent I know you're not fond of.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: Hush!‚ÄîKnows you are come home! What, this is your home then?

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Why, father, the‚Äîthe‚Äîthe‚Äî

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p: The‚Äîthe‚ÄîI thought there was something damn'd odd about that Emperor of Moroco's Jailer, and I suppose you will tell me now, the Count is the Emperor himself.

sp.speaker: YOUNG FLOURISH.
sp.p: Come, father, the truth must out‚ÄîThe two different systems of education have at last been compleated in the same college; and though I don't think keeping Terms here absolutely necessary for the finish of every young gentleman's education; yet, as a school of adversity it has taught me this lesson‚ÄîNever, by folly and extravagance, to run the chance of returning, when once you do me the honour to take my name out of the books

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN O'NEIL.
sp.p: Come, you must forgive him. You know the brave are always compassionate.

sp.speaker: SIR SIMON FLOURISH.
sp.p:
Very true; besides, it is useless to repine at
what is past, especially as you acknowledge you have learn'd some good, which I am not quite sure you wou d have done by travelling‚ÄîAnd if your friends here will be but indulgent, you may‚ñ™ possess all the credit of going Abroad with the advantage of having remained at Home.

lg.l: Now put an end to silly strife,
Malice is but folly;
Let's wisely pass a merry life,
Waste no jot in care.
Why that's well said, come, let's away
With hearts good humour'd, faces gay,
And sing fal, lal, &c.
Possessing all I prize on earth,
Farewel, melancholy,
Each hour will give new pleasure birth,
Blest with thee, my fair.
Then tune to joy the dulcet note,
On harmony let pleasure float,
And sing fal, lal, &c.
To harmony I don't object,
While I've luck to meet it;
In home duets I can't expect
Much of harmony.
Come let's be wise, and from this day,
With hearts good humour'd, faces gay,
We'll sing fal, lal, &c.
Our mirth and joy may all partake,
Humbly I intreat it,
And let your cheering plaudits make
Our poet full of glee.
Then tune to joy the dulcet note,
On harmony let pleasure float,
And sing fal, lal, &c.
